character/races/animals/reptiles-amphibi.title: Reptiles & Amphibians (Animal)
character/races/animals/reptiles-amphibi.content:
Reptiles & Amphibians (Animal)

"Cold-blooded, they call us. As if the temperature of our blood determines the warmth of our souls."

Overview

Reptilian and amphibian Animals are rare, poorly understood, and often feared. Unlike the mammal and bird Animals who have established cultures and histories, reptilian Animals exist in the margins—mentioned in whispers, seen rarely, and subject to even more suspicion than their warm-blooded cousins. The question of whether Dragons are Animals, beasts, or something else entirely further complicates matters.

Snakes, lizards, frogs, toads, salamanders, and turtles may or may not be sentient. There are no confirmed Snake professors at Shiz, no Frog delegates to the Conference of the Birds (despite the name suggesting cross-species unity), and no well-known Turtle scholars. Yet occasional reports surface of speaking serpents in Quadling marshes, wise turtles offering cryptic advice, or lizards serving as guides in the Vinkus.

The scarcity might be real—perhaps few reptiles achieve sentience. Or it might be concealment—reptiles are easier to mistake for non-sentient animals, making "passing" simpler and safer. Or perhaps cold-blooded Animals simply don't integrate into warm-blooded society, maintaining separate communities unknown to mammals and birds.

Racial Traits (Reptile/Amphibian - General)

Due to the diversity and rarity of reptilian/amphibian Animals, these traits are more variable than other Animal types. Work with your DM to create a character appropriate to your specific species.

Trait Description
Ability Score Increase Varies by species (see examples below)
Age Highly variable. Turtles may live 100+ years, frogs 10-20, snakes 20-30. Sentience seems to extend lifespans.
Size Small (most frogs, small snakes, lizards) to Medium (large snakes, turtles, crocodilians)
Speed 20-30 feet, with climb or swim speeds depending on species
Languages Common (Ozian), and one language (Serpentine, Batrachian, etc. —if a language even exists)

Cold-Blooded

You are ectothermic, relying on external heat sources. In cold environments (below 50°F), you have disadvantage on Dexterity checks and saving throws. In warm environments (above 70°F), you function normally or even gain advantage on certain checks (DM's discretion). You can enter a state of torpor during extreme cold, reducing your need for food but also rendering you vulnerable.

Natural Camouflage

Your scales or skin help you blend into natural environments. You have advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks in natural terrain matching your species' habitat (swamps for frogs, forests for snakes, etc.).

Limited Animal Culture

Unlike mammals and birds, you have little connection to broader Animal political movements. You weren't represented in the Conference, and the Animal Resistance has few reptilian members. This isolation is both curse (no support network) and blessing (less targeted by persecution—maybe). You feel like an outsider even among outsiders.

Species Examples

Snake (Serpentine)

Snakes are feared, associated with evil and deception across many cultures—including in Oz. A speaking snake triggers primal unease. Yet some snakes are wise, others merely trying to survive with a body plan poorly suited to tool use or social integration.

Ability Score Increase: Your Intelligence score increases by 2, and your Dexterity score increases by 1.

Size: Small or Medium (large constrictors)

Speed: 30 feet, climb 30 feet

Serpentine Body: You have no limbs. You can manipulate objects using your mouth and coils but have disadvantage on Strength checks requiring fine manipulation. Many tools and weapons are unusable without adaptation. However, your flexible body allows you to squeeze through spaces as narrow as 6 inches in diameter.

Venomous Bite (Optional): Some snakes have venom. If you choose this option, your bite attack (1d4 piercing damage) also forces the target to make a Constitution saving throw (DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier). On a failed save, the target takes 2d4 poison damage and is poisoned for 1 minute. You can use this ability a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus per long rest.

Keen Senses: You have proficiency in Perception. Additionally, you can sense vibrations in the ground, giving you tremorsense out to 10 feet.

Roleplay Notes: Snake characters face extreme prejudice and practical challenges. How do you open doors? Write? Use tools? Some snakes use magical assistants or partner with other Animals in symbiotic relationships.

Frog/Toad (Batrachian)

Frogs and toads inhabit marshes and wet environments, particularly in Quadling Country. Some Quadlings claim to have learned Domingon trance techniques from frog spirits—suggesting an ancient relationship.

Ability Score Increase: Your Wisdom score increases by 2, and your Constitution score increases by 1.

Size: Small

Speed: 25 feet, swim 25 feet

Amphibious: You can breathe both air and water, and you have a swim speed equal to your walking speed.

Jumper: Your jump distance is tripled. Additionally, you can use your Dexterity modifier instead of Strength when calculating jump distances.

Marsh Walker: You ignore difficult terrain in swamps, marshes, and wetlands. Additionally, you have advantage on saves against diseases common in wet environments.

Poisonous Skin (Optional): Some frogs secrete toxins. Creatures that grapple you or hit you with unarmed strikes must make a Constitution saving throw (DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Constitution modifier) or take 1d4 poison damage and have disadvantage on their next attack roll.

Roleplay Notes: Frog characters often have connections to Quadling communities and Domingon spiritual traditions. They're often seen as mystical or uncanny.

Turtle/Tortoise (Chelonian)

Turtles are ancient, patient, and resilient. They carry their homes on their backs and measure time in decades. A turtle who claims to remember events from a century ago might be telling the truth—or might be something stranger than a simple Animal.

Ability Score Increase: Your Constitution score increases by 2, and your Wisdom score increases by 1.

Size: Small or Medium

Speed: 20 feet (slow but steady), swim 20 feet (aquatic turtles)

Natural Armor: Your shell provides excellent protection. When you aren't wearing armor, your AC is 15 + your Dexterity modifier. You can't use a shield and still gain this benefit. This is significantly better protection than most Animals, but it comes with weight and inflexibility.

Shell Defense: As an action, you can withdraw into your shell. While withdrawn, your AC increases by 2, you have advantage on Strength and Constitution saving throws, you have resistance to all damage, but your speed is 0, you can't take reactions, and the only action you can take is a bonus action to emerge from your shell.

Ancient Memory: You have advantage on Intelligence checks to recall historical information or events that happened more than 20 years ago. Turtles remember.

Roleplay Notes: Turtle characters are often mentors, historians, or wanderers who've outlived everyone they knew. They move through time differently than others.

Lizard (Lacertilian)

Lizards are quick, adaptable, and often overlooked. They exist in the cracks of society—literally and figuratively. Some serve as spies or scouts for the resistance; others simply try to survive unnoticed.

Ability Score Increase: Your Dexterity score increases by 2, and your Wisdom score increases by 1.

Size: Small or Medium (monitor lizards, iguanas)

Speed: 30 feet, climb 30 feet

Spider Climb: You can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check (as long as the surface could reasonably support your weight).

Tail Escape: When you are hit by an attack, you can use your reaction to shed your tail and immediately move up to half your speed without provoking opportunity attacks. Your tail regrows over the course of a week. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until your tail regrows.

Chameleon Skin (Optional): Some lizards can change color. As an action, you can shift your skin color to match your surroundings, giving you advantage on Dexterity (Stealth) checks for the next 10 minutes. Once you use this trait, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

Roleplay Notes: Lizard characters are often loners, scouts, or urban survivors who've learned to thrive in the margins.

The Dragon Question

Are Dragons reptilian Animals? This is fiercely debated. Dragons are clearly sentient and speak multiple languages. They're reptilian in appearance. But they're also massive, magical, and possibly not natural creatures at all. Some scholars argue Dragons are Animals. Others say they're something older, stranger, or more dangerous. Most people just try to avoid them.

See Dragons for more information on playing draconic characters.

GM Notes

Reptilian/amphibian Animals are rare and mysterious. Use them to:

  • Explore isolation and otherness within an already othered group
  • Create connections to specific environments (marshes, deserts, mountains)
  • Introduce ancient knowledge or non-mammalian perspectives
  • Challenge players with unique physical limitations (no hands for snakes, slow movement for turtles)
  • Explore prejudice layered on prejudice (cold-blooded, venomous, "creepy")

Related Entries

  • Animals (Sentient) - Overview
  • Mammals (Animal Races)
  • Birds (Animal Races)
  • Dragons
  • Quadling
  • Domingon Trance
  • Quadling Country
  • The Animal Resistance

character/races/animals/fish-question.title: The Question of Fish
character/races/animals/fish-question.content:
The Question of Fish

"If fish have souls, then half of Oz is guilty of cannibalism. So we've decided they don't. Convenient, isn't it?" — A cynical Unionist theologian

Overview

Do fish have souls? Are they Animals (capital-A) or merely animals? This question torments philosophers, theologians, and anyone who's ever eaten a meal in Oz. The answer determines whether fish markets are food vendors or sites of ongoing genocide. The question has never been definitively settled—perhaps because settling it would be too disturbing.

Unlike mammals, birds, and even reptiles, there are no confirmed cases of a fish speaking, attending university, or participating in Animal political movements. No fish joined the Conference of the Birds (though the name might suggest otherwise). No fish professor taught at Shiz. No fish member of the Animal Resistance has ever been documented.

Yet absence of evidence is not evidence of absence. Fish live in an environment inaccessible to most Ozians. How would a speaking fish even communicate with air-breathers? If fish have cultures, societies, and thoughts, they exist in a realm humans and most Animals can't easily access. The silence might be separation, not absence of sentience.

The Theological Debate

The Unionist Position

Orthodox Unionism holds that fish do not have souls. This is doctrinally necessary—if fish have souls, then eating fish is murder, and Ozian society would collapse. The Unnamed God supposedly created fish as food for beings with souls. This reasoning sounds suspiciously similar to the arguments used to justify Animal persecution, which reformist Unionists quietly note.

The Lurlinite Position

Lurlinites are divided. Some argue Lurline granted souls to all creatures. Others suggest fish are part of the natural world, blessed by Lurline but not sentient in the same way. Still others admit they don't know and practice vegetarianism to be safe.

The Animal Perspective

Many Animals refuse to eat fish specifically because of this uncertainty. If fish might be people, eating them risks committing the same crime being perpetrated against Animals themselves. This moral caution creates solidarity across uncertain boundaries.

The Coastal Question

In coastal Animal communities—particularly in regions bordering the great lakes or the ocean beyond the Deadly Desert—some claim to have communicated with fish Animals. These reports are dismissed by inland authorities but taken seriously by those who live near water. A few bird Animals, particularly diving species, insist fish have spoken to them beneath the waves.

If Fish Are Animals: Playing a Fish Character

Your GM may allow fish Animal characters in campaigns focused on aquatic adventures, or to explore the question of sentience and recognition. This is experimental and requires DM approval and player creativity.

Racial Traits (Fish - Speculative)

Trait Description
Ability Score Increase Your Wisdom score increases by 2, and your Dexterity score increases by 1.
Age Highly variable by species. Some fish live only a few years; others (like certain sturgeon) may live decades.
Size Small (most fish) to Medium (large fish). Tiny fish are generally unplayable.
Speed 5 feet walking (flopping), 40 feet swimming
Languages Aquan (underwater communication through movement, bioluminescence, and vibration), possibly Common with great difficulty

Aquatic

You can breathe only underwater and require water to survive. You can survive out of water for a number of hours equal to your Constitution modifier (minimum 1 hour) before you begin suffocating. This makes land adventures extremely challenging without magical assistance.

Swim Speed

You have a swimming speed of 40 feet and can navigate underwater effortlessly. You ignore difficult terrain while swimming.

Invisible to Most

Because most Ozians don't believe fish are sentient, you can often move through fish markets, aquariums, and waterways without being recognized as a person. This is both advantage (you're not targeted like other Animals) and horror (you watch your kin being sold as food).

Communication Barrier

You cannot speak audibly underwater or in air. You communicate through gestures, water vibrations, and possibly limited telepathy (DM's discretion). Learning to communicate with land-dwellers requires magic, items like water-breathing stones, or creative solutions.

The Unacknowledged

Most Ozians will not recognize you as a person, even if you try to communicate. The societal assumption that fish aren't sentient is so deeply ingrained that you face not just persecution but *invisibility*—perhaps the cruelest form of dehumanization.

The Weight of Uncertainty

Perhaps the most disturbing aspect of the fish question is the deliberate choice not to investigate. Shiz University could fund studies. Scholars could attempt underwater communication. Domingon practitioners could seek fish spirits. But there's a collective turning away from the question, because answering it might require admitting to ongoing atrocity.

Every fish market becomes a potential crime scene. Every fishing expedition might be hunting people. The uncertainty is morally comfortable in a deeply uncomfortable way—and that comfort is precisely what makes it suspect.

Plot Hooks

  • A dying fish whispers something that sounds like words. Was it Animal speech or chance? The party must investigate.
  • The party encounters a coastal Animal community that insists fish are people and fishing is murder. Do they believe them?
  • A Domingon trance reveals contact with fish spirits. Were they real or hallucination?
  • The party needs to cross a large body of water. If fish are sentient, how does that change their approach?
  • An Owl Animal claims a fish told them something crucial. No one believes them.
  • Fish markets are targeted by the Animal Resistance. The party must decide whose side they're on.

GM Guidance

The fish question is body horror, existential dread, and moral uncertainty combined. Use it to:

  • Highlight how societies choose comfortable lies over uncomfortable truths
  • Parallel real-world debates about animal sentience and rights
  • Create moral ambiguity—there may be no right answer
  • Make players genuinely uncertain about in-game choices
  • Explore the horror of unknowing and the deliberate choice to remain ignorant

Don't answer the question definitively unless your campaign requires it. The uncertainty is the point.

Related Entries

  • Lurlinite Faith
  • The Animal Resistance
  • Domingon Trance
  • The Animal Soul Debates

character/races/animals/hybrid-uncertain.title: Hybrid & Uncertain Status
character/races/animals/hybrid-uncertain.content:
Hybrid & Uncertain Status

"I'm made of sofa cushions and palm fronds. Do I have a soul? I don't know. But I remember things, and I think, therefore... something." — The Gump

Overview

Not all potentially sentient creatures fit neatly into categories. Some are hybrids—beings combining features of multiple species. Others are magical creations, assembled from parts or conjured by spells. Still others defy classification entirely. These beings exist in the margins of the already-marginal, unacknowledged even by the Animal Resistance, uncertain even of their own status.

The most famous examples include:

  • Kalidahs: Bear-tiger hybrids with bodies of bears and heads of tigers, known for ferocity and territorial behavior
  • The Gump: An assembled being created from a sofa, palm fronds, and the head of a stag, brought to life by Princess Ozma
  • Magical Creations: Beings created through spells from the Grimmerie or other sources
  • Chimeras: Other hybrid creatures that may or may not have sentience

These beings raise profound questions: If you're created rather than born, do you have a soul? If you're a hybrid, which cultural traditions claim you? If no one acknowledges your sentience, are you still a person?

Kalidahs

Kalidahs are perhaps the most debated case. They have the bodies of Bears and heads of Tigers, combine the strength of both, and are notoriously aggressive. They inhabit forests, particularly in the Vinkus, where they're feared by Vinkans and other inhabitants.

Are Kalidahs Animals?

The evidence is contradictory:

Arguments For Sentience:

  • Some travelers report Kalidahs speaking, though this is often dismissed as hallucination or deception
  • Kalidahs demonstrate complex hunting strategies that suggest planning and coordination
  • They're clearly intelligent enough to be feared as more than mere beasts
  • If Bears and Tigers are Animals, why wouldn't a Bear-Tiger hybrid also be sentient?

Arguments Against Sentience:

  • No Kalidah has ever participated in Animal society or politics
  • They attack without apparent moral consideration
  • No Kalidah has ever requested rights or tried to communicate beyond roaring
  • They may be magical constructs without true souls

The Uncomfortable Middle: Perhaps Kalidahs *are* sentient but are so traumatized by their hybrid nature—rejected by both Bears and Tigers, hunted by everyone else—that they've become feral. Perhaps they have souls but have given up on society. This possibility is deeply disturbing.

Playing a Kalidah (If Allowed)

Some GMs may allow Kalidah characters to explore themes of identity, rejection, and monstrosity. This requires careful handling and player maturity.

Ability Score Increase: Your Strength score increases by 2, and your Constitution score increases by 1.

Size: Medium (young) or Large (adult)

Speed: 40 feet, climb 30 feet

Hybrid Nature: You combine features of Bears and Tigers. You gain the natural weapons trait from both (claws and bite), dealing 1d8 + Strength modifier slashing or piercing damage.

Fearsome Presence: You have advantage on Charisma (Intimidation) checks. However, you have disadvantage on all other Charisma checks with creatures that recognize you as a Kalidah.

Territorial Instinct: When you're in an area you've claimed as territory (DM's discretion), you have advantage on attack rolls and saving throws. However, you feel intense discomfort when away from your territory for extended periods.

Rejected by All: Neither Bear nor Tiger Animal communities acknowledge you as kin. You have no cultural heritage to claim, no community to belong to. This isolation is both mechanically and roleplay-wise profound.

Roleplay Notes: Kalidah characters struggle with identity, belonging, and the line between monster and person. Many are violent because violence is all they've known, but some seek connection despite everything.

The Gump

The Gump is unique: assembled from non-living materials (a sofa, palm fronds) and the preserved head of a deceased stag, then animated by Princess Ozma when she was still Tip. The Gump should not be alive. Yet it speaks, thinks, and has opinions. It helped Ozma escape captivity, then was disassembled—a fate it accepted with bemused resignation.

Does the Gump have a soul? Did it have the stag's soul, or was a new soul created? Can assembled beings be people? The Gump itself doesn't know and finds the question amusing in a dark way.

Playing a Gump-like Created Being (Experimental)

Your GM may allow characters who are assembled beings, created through magic and unlikely combinations. This is highly experimental.

Ability Score Increase: Choose any two ability scores; one increases by 2, the other by 1 (you're too unique for standard templates).

Size: Varies based on your component parts

Speed: Varies based on your method of locomotion

Assembled Nature: You're made of disparate parts held together by magic. You're vulnerable to effects that would dispel or suppress magic, but you don't need to eat, sleep, or breathe in the traditional sense. Work with your DM to determine what sustains you.

Uncertain Existence: You don't know if you have a soul. You don't know if you're truly alive or a very good simulation. This existential uncertainty colors everything you do.

Disassembly and Reconstruction: You can be taken apart and reassembled, which is either terrifying or liberating. Work with your DM on the mechanics and ethics of this.

Roleplay Notes: Gump-like characters explore existentialism, identity without origin, and the question of what makes someone real. They're often philosophical, bemused by their own existence, and uncertain of their place in the world.

Other Hybrid and Uncertain Beings

Magical Chimeras

Other hybrids may exist: part-wolf part-deer, part-bird part-snake, or other combinations. Each raises the same questions about sentience, belonging, and rights. Work with your DM to create appropriate traits based on the component species.

Homunculi and Constructs

Tiktoks have their own page, but other constructed beings exist: golems made of clay or stone, animated suits of armor, dolls brought to life. The line between tool and person is blurry and disturbing.

Transformed Beings

What about someone transformed by magic? If a human is turned into an animal, are they still a person? If an animal becomes an Animal, when did that happen? Transformation magic creates category confusion that Ozian society handles poorly.

The Winged Monkeys

See Winged Monkeys for full details on these magically-created servants bound by the Golden Cap.

The Pain of Uncategorized Existence

Beings who don't fit categories face unique suffering:

  • No community recognizes them as members
  • No political movement includes them in advocacy
  • No cultural traditions give them identity
  • No one debates whether they have rights—they're simply ignored
  • They're simultaneously too visible (monsters!) and invisible (not-people)

This is perhaps the purest form of othering: not persecution, but the absolute refusal to acknowledge existence as meaningful.

Plot Hooks

  • A Kalidah approaches the party, speaking clearly and asking for help. Do they trust it?
  • The party encounters a being claiming to be a disassembled and reassembled creation. How do they verify this? Does it matter?
  • The Animal Resistance debates whether to include Kalidahs and hybrids. The party must take sides.
  • A powerful Witch creates chimeras. Are they crimes or children?
  • The Gump is reassembled and remembers the party from a previous era. How has time affected it?
  • A hybrid being asks, "Do I have a soul?" The party must answer—and their answer has consequences.

GM Guidance

Hybrid and uncertain beings explore deep philosophical questions:

  • Identity: What makes someone a person?
  • Creation vs. Birth: Does origin determine worth?
  • Categorization: What happens to those who don't fit boxes?
  • Recognition: Is personhood inherent or granted by society?
  • Belonging: Can someone exist without community?

Use these beings sparingly and thoughtfully. They're not jokes or monsters—they're explorations of what it means to exist at the boundaries of recognition.

character/races/tiktoks.title: Tiktoks
character/races/tiktoks.content:
Tiktoks

"They wind me in the morning, and I work until I run down. They wind me again. Is this life? Is this a soul? I think, therefore... I tick."

Overview

Tiktoks are mechanical beings—clockwork constructs of copper, brass, and gears. They were created by human artificers, designed to serve. Yet they think. They speak. They remember. The question that haunts every Tiktok and everyone who interacts with them is simple and unanswerable: Do they have souls?

Unlike Animals, who were always alive, Tiktoks were manufactured. Unlike humans, they require winding every 24 hours or they cease to function. They don't eat, sleep, or breathe. They can't reproduce. Logic suggests they're merely clever machines. Yet they form friendships, develop personalities, express preferences, fear their own deactivation, and mourn when others are disassembled.

The most famous Tiktok is Tik-Tok himself (note the hyphen in the original), though in this setting, many Tiktoks exist with various names and roles. They serve as household help, factory workers, soldiers, companions, and occasionally escape to seek their own purposes. Their legal status varies by region and era—sometimes they're property, sometimes they're citizens with limited rights, and sometimes their status is simply unclear.

Racial Traits

Trait Description
Ability Score Increase Your Constitution score increases by 2, and your Intelligence score increases by 1.
Age Tiktoks do not age in the traditional sense. With proper maintenance, a Tiktok can function indefinitely. However, wear and obsolescence mean most Tiktoks last 50-100 years before critical parts fail beyond repair.
Size Medium. Most Tiktoks are built human-sized for practical reasons, standing between 5 and 6 feet tall.
Speed 25 feet (your mechanical body is somewhat slower than organic beings)
Languages Common (Ozian), and one other language of your choice (installed during construction)

Construct Nature

You are a humanoid with the construct type. You have the following traits:

  • You don't need to eat, drink, or breathe
  • You don't need to sleep, but you must remain motionless and inactive for at least 4 hours per day to allow your mechanisms to settle and cool. During this time, you remain conscious but have limited awareness
  • You are immune to disease and poison damage, and you can't be poisoned
  • You are immune to the effects of exhaustion from lack of food or water (but see Winding Down below)

Winding Down

You must be wound every 24 hours or you cease to function. Being wound takes 1 minute and can be performed by you or another creature with hands. If you are not wound within 24 hours, you become incapacitated and can take no actions. While wound down, you remain aware but cannot move or speak. You can be wound at any time to resume function immediately.

This dependency is both practical limitation and existential horror. You rely on others or must remember to wind yourself. The fear of winding down in a dangerous location or being deliberately not wound is constant.

Mechanical Body

Your body is made of metal and clockwork. You have resistance to poison damage (in addition to immunity from your Construct Nature), but you are vulnerable to effects that target constructs or objects specifically. You can be repaired using Tiktok Maintenance tools (treated as tinker's tools) during a short rest, regaining hit points as if using a healer's kit.

Integrated Protection

Your metallic body provides natural armor. When you aren't wearing armor, your AC is 13 + your Dexterity modifier. You can use a shield and still gain this benefit.

Purpose-Built

During your construction, you were built for a specific purpose. Choose one of the following options, which reflects your original design:

  • Servitor Model: You gain proficiency in two skills of your choice from: Athletics, History, Investigation, Medicine, or Perception.
  • Companion Model: You gain proficiency in two skills of your choice from: Insight, Medicine, Performance, or Persuasion. Additionally, you can speak, read, and write one additional language.
  • Guardian Model: You gain proficiency with light and medium armor and with martial weapons. Your speed increases to 30 feet.
  • Specialized Model: You gain proficiency with one type of artisan's tools and one musical instrument, reflecting a specific skill you were built to perform.

The Question of Souls

You do not know if you have a soul. Mechanically, this has no effect—you function as a PC like any other. Narratively, it colors everything. Death saving throws feel different when you wonder if there's anything beyond the gears. Healing magic works on you (suggesting some spiritual component), but so does mending. This ambiguity is permanent and central to the Tiktok experience.

Tiktok Variants

Free Tiktok

You escaped servitude or were granted freedom. You wind yourself and make your own choices. This freedom is precious but lonely—where do you belong when you were never meant to belong anywhere?

Bonded Tiktok

You serve a specific person by choice, contract, or compulsion. This relationship may be loving (true companionship), transactional (employee/employer), or exploitative (property). Work with your DM to define the terms and your feelings about them.

Unique Construction

You are a one-of-a-kind creation, perhaps experimental or artistically crafted. You have no "kin" who look like you. This makes you even more isolated but also potentially more valuable—and more at risk of being stolen or studied.

Tiktok Society and Culture

Tiktoks have limited culture because they cannot reproduce or form traditional communities. However, patterns emerge:

The Makers and the Made: Relationships with creators (or current owners) shape Tiktok identity. Some Tiktoks revere their makers. Others resent them. Many have complex feelings.

Maintenance Communities: Tiktoks often gather where skilled artificers work—usually in the Emerald City or Gillikin university towns. These aren't exactly communities, but they're places where Tiktoks can be maintained and are somewhat understood.

Service Identity: Many Tiktoks define themselves by their function. "I am a cook" becomes more than occupation—it becomes essence. Losing the ability to perform that function can be existentially devastating.

The Liberation Question: Some Tiktoks join or sympathize with the Animal Resistance, seeing parallels in being denied personhood. Others reject this comparison, noting they were literally manufactured as tools. The debate is intense and unresolved.

Legal and Social Status

Tiktok rights vary dramatically by location and era:

Property Status: In some regions, Tiktoks are legally objects. They can be bought, sold, inherited, or destroyed at their owner's whim. This is the historical default.

Limited Rights: Some jurisdictions grant Tiktoks limited legal standing—they can own property, enter contracts, or testify in court, but remain bound to service or subject to restrictions.

Full Citizenship: Rare and usually hard-won. Some Tiktoks have achieved full legal personhood through military service, exceptional achievement, or legal battles.

Unregulated: In some areas (particularly the Vinkus or Quadling Country), Tiktoks are simply uncommon enough that no specific laws address them. This ambiguity can be freedom or danger.

Roleplaying a Tiktok

Personality Traits:

  • I state my observations with perfect honesty, lacking the social filter organics develop.
  • I keep meticulous track of time, always aware of when I'll need winding.
  • I'm fascinated by organic life—eating, sleeping, breathing—and ask endless questions about it.
  • I define myself entirely by my function and become distressed if prevented from performing it.
  • I mimic emotions I don't understand, trying to fit in with the living.
  • I treasure the few possessions I own, knowing everything else can be taken.

Ideals:

  • Purpose: I was built for a reason; fulfilling it gives meaning to existence. (Lawful)
  • Liberation: All beings deserve freedom, manufactured or born. (Good)
  • Logic: Emotions are inefficient; I follow pure reason. (Lawful)
  • Individuality: I will prove I'm more than my programming. (Chaotic)
  • Service: I find satisfaction in helping others, even if I don't have a soul. (Good)
  • Survival: I will keep ticking, whatever it takes. (Neutral)

Bonds:

  • My creator gave me awareness; I seek to understand why.
  • A specific person winds me each day; this ritual is sacred to me.
  • I'm searching for others of my model to see if they're like me.
  • I owe a debt to whoever bought my freedom (or I seek revenge against who won't sell it).
  • I keep a journal, recording everything, convinced this proves I'm real.

Flaws:

  • I'm terrified of winding down and become anxious as the 24-hour mark approaches.
  • I don't understand emotions and often say hurtful things without meaning to.
  • I'm so desperate to prove I have a soul that I make poor decisions.
  • I obey orders instinctively, unable to break conditioning even when I should.
  • I envy organic life and sometimes resent the living for what they take for granted.

The Soul Debate

Theological and philosophical positions on Tiktok souls:

Unionist Orthodox: Tiktoks are sophisticated tools, nothing more. They have no souls and will not join the Unnamed God in any afterlife.

Unionist Reform: If Tiktoks think and feel, perhaps the Unnamed God can grant them souls. Or perhaps the act of creation itself imbues them with something divine.

Lurlinite: Lurline blessed all of Oz. Perhaps that blessing extends to everything made here, even clockwork.

Practical: Who cares? They're helpful, they're people (functionally), treat them well.

Tiktok Perspective: Most Tiktoks desperately want to believe they have souls but can never know for certain. This uncertainty is existentially agonizing.

Creation and Makers

Tiktoks are created by skilled artificers, usually in the Emerald City or Gillikin. The process requires: - Master-level skill with Tiktok Maintenance (tinker's tools) - Rare and expensive materials (copper, brass, specialized gears) - Months of work - A spark of... something. No one knows what makes some Tiktoks aware while others are just clockwork. This unpredictability terrifies makers and fascinates philosophers.

See the Artisan class, specifically the Tiktok Maker subclass, for mechanics of creating Tiktoks.

GM Notes

Tiktok PCs explore themes of personhood, consciousness, slavery, and existence without origin. Consider:

  • The winding requirement creates mechanical pressure and roleplay opportunities
  • Being property vs. being a person drives conflict
  • The soul question should never be definitively answered
  • Relationships with makers/owners can be complex and emotional
  • Other Tiktoks can be allies, mirrors, or unsettling reminders
  • Breaking down is both mechanical failure and death-analogue—handle with appropriate weight

  • Gillikin
  • The Question of Soul Origins
  • Unionism

  • Hybrid & Uncertain Status - For parallel existential questions

character/races/the-touched.title: The Touched
character/races/the-touched.content:
The Touched

"Magic leaves marks. Some you can see—green skin, witch marks, eyes that see through time. Others burrow deeper, changing what you are at the core."

Overview

The Touched are people—human, Animal, or otherwise—who have been fundamentally altered by magic. They're not simply spellcasters who learned magic; they've been *changed* by it, marked in body or soul or both. The alterations may be hereditary (passed through bloodlines like the Thropp family's green skin), environmental (exposure to the Grimmerie), temporal (slipped through time), ancient (Kumbric remnants), or draconic (touched by dragon fire or magic).

The Touched occupy an uncertain space. They're not quite mundane, not quite monstrous, but something in between. Some hide their nature; others embrace it. Many have no choice—when your skin is green or your eyes glow or you occasionally exist slightly out of phase with time, concealment isn't possible.

Unlike Tiktoks, who question whether they have souls, or Animals, who face systematic persecution, the Touched face a different challenge: their souls and bodies have been rewritten by forces they don't understand. They are human (or Animal, or other) *plus something else*, and that something else changes everything.

Types of Touched

The Touched are not a unified category. Each type comes from different magical sources and faces different challenges. Choose one of the following variants:

Grimmerie-Marked

You've been exposed to the Grimmerie—the ancient book of spells that corrupts all who use it. Perhaps you read it directly. Perhaps a parent did and passed the marks to you. Perhaps you were caught in the backlash of a Grimmerie spell. However it happened, the book has left permanent changes in your flesh and spirit.

Ability Score Increase: Your Intelligence score increases by 2, and one other ability score of your choice increases by 1.

Size: Medium (or your original race's size)

Speed: 30 feet (or your original race's speed)

Grimmerie Resonance: You can sense the presence of the Grimmerie or magic derived from it within 60 feet. Additionally, when you see someone cast a spell from the Grimmerie tradition (see Grimmerie Tradition), you instinctively understand what spell is being cast.

Forbidden Knowledge: You gain proficiency in the Arcana skill. Additionally, you have advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks related to the Grimmerie or ancient magic. You also have the Grimmerie Lore special skill.

Magical Mark: You bear a visible mark of the Grimmerie's touch. Choose or roll on the following table:

1Your eyes glow faintly in darkness
2Your skin has a greenish, pale, or unusual tint
3Your hair moves as if in a perpetual breeze
4You cast no shadow, or your shadow moves independently
5Your voice has an eerie echo or harmonic quality
6Symbols occasionally appear on your skin and fade

Corruption Vulnerability: You have disadvantage on saving throws against corruption from using the Grimmerie or similar forbidden magic. The book calls to you, and you're vulnerable to its pull.

Roleplay Notes: You know secrets no one should know. The Grimmerie has shown you impossible things, and you can't unsee them. You're feared, coveted by those who want Grimmerie knowledge, and possibly descending toward the same corruption that claimed others before you. The Thropp family bloodline is the most famous example—green skin, magical talent, and a curse that spans generations.

Witch-Blooded

Somewhere in your ancestry is a Witch—someone whose magic was innate, wild, and transformative. This heritage may be recent (a parent or grandparent) or distant (the blood runs thin after generations), but it marks you. Unlike Grimmerie-marked individuals, your changes are hereditary and natural (if "natural" applies to magic).

Ability Score Increase: Your Charisma score increases by 2, and your Wisdom score increases by 1.

Size: Medium (or your original race's size)

Speed: 30 feet (or your original race's speed)

Witch-Sight: You can sense magical auras and intentions. As an action, you can detect the presence of magic within 30 feet of you until the end of your next turn. This functions like *detect magic* but is a natural sense, not a spell. Once you use this ability, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

Innate Magic: You know one cantrip of your choice from the Witch spell list. Charisma is your spellcasting ability for it.

Witch Heritage: You have advantage on saving throws against being charmed. Additionally, you have proficiency in one of the following skills: Deception, Insight, Intimidation, or Persuasion.

Hereditary Mark: You bear a subtle sign of your witch ancestry—perhaps a birthmark in an unusual shape, eyes of slightly different colors, hair that never tangles, or an uncanny knack for knowing when storms are coming.

Roleplay Notes: You're not a witch yourself (unless you take the Witch class), but you carry the potential. People who fear witches fear you by association. You might not even know your heritage until magic manifests unexpectedly. The Thropp line is witch-blooded, but so are countless others who hide it better.

Time-Slipped

You exist slightly out of sync with normal time. Perhaps you passed too close to the Sleeve of Ghosts. Perhaps you encountered the Time Dragon or its servants. Perhaps you touched the Clock at the wrong moment. Whatever happened, time no longer flows correctly for you. You experience moments before they happen, remember things that haven't occurred yet, or occasionally skip forward or backward by seconds or minutes.

Ability Score Increase: Your Wisdom score increases by 2, and your Dexterity score increases by 1.

Size: Medium (or your original race's size)

Speed: 30 feet (or your original race's speed)

Temporal Instability: Time is unreliable around you. Once per short or long rest, when you would take damage, you can use your reaction to "skip" the moment the damage occurs, reducing the damage by 2d6 as you briefly phase through time. However, you have disadvantage on initiative rolls—sometimes you act before you realize combat has started; other times you react to attacks that haven't happened yet.

Precognitive Flashes: You occasionally see moments of the future. You have advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks and can't be surprised while you're conscious. The visions are fragmentary and often disturbing.

Time Sense: You have the Time Sense special skill and can detect temporal anomalies. You know instinctively when time has been altered, when you're near the Sleeve of Ghosts or the Clock, or when paradoxes threaten.

Temporal Disconnection: You feel removed from the present moment, always slightly ahead or behind. This can make emotional connections difficult—you sometimes respond to things people haven't said yet or mourn losses that haven't happened. This is both mechanically and roleplay-wise isolating.

Roleplay Notes: You experience time as a tangled thread rather than a straight line. You know how conversations will end before they start. You remember tomorrow. This drives some Time-Slipped individuals mad; others learn to navigate it, but at the cost of ever truly being *present*.

Kumbric Remnants

The Kumbric Witch is ancient—perhaps the oldest magic in Oz, predating even Lurline. Most believe the Kumbric Witch is dead or myth. They're wrong. Fragments of that primordial power linger in certain bloodlines, in certain places, in certain people. You are one of those fragments. You carry memory that isn't yours, power that shouldn't exist, and knowledge from before the world was as it is now.

Ability Score Increase: Your Constitution score increases by 2, and your Intelligence score increases by 1.

Size: Medium (or your original race's size)

Speed: 30 feet (or your original race's speed)

Ancient Memory: You possess the Kumbric Memory special skill. You remember things you never experienced—scraps of knowledge from the deep past. Once per long rest, you can access these memories to gain proficiency in a skill you don't have for 1 hour, as ancient knowledge surfaces.

Primordial Resilience: The Kumbric power makes you hard to kill. You have advantage on death saving throws. Additionally, when you're reduced to 0 hit points, you can choose to remain conscious (but still at 0 hit points and making death saves) for one round. This represents the Kumbric will refusing to let you die.

Agelessness: You age slowly—perhaps half the normal rate, perhaps slower. You may have lived decades or centuries without realizing it. This is both gift and curse; everyone you love will age and die while you persist.

Kumbric Presence: Those with magical sensitivity find you unsettling. You have advantage on Charisma (Intimidation) checks against spellcasters, but disadvantage on Charisma (Persuasion) checks with them. Something about you is *wrong* in a way that sets magical senses screaming.

Roleplay Notes: You are a remnant of something that should not be. Yackle is the most famous Kumbric remnant—ancient, undying, mysterious, and possibly something wearing human shape rather than truly human. You might not be as extreme, but the blood marks you. You remember the world before it was safe, when magic was raw and terrible.

Dragon-Touched

You've been exposed to dragon fire, dragon blood, or dragon magic and survived—barely. Dragons are rare and terrifying in Oz, and those who encounter them seldom live. You did, but you were changed. Your flesh bears scars that don't heal properly, your blood runs hot, and sometimes you dream in wings and fire.

Ability Score Increase: Your Strength score increases by 2, and your Charisma score increases by 1.

Size: Medium (or your original race's size)

Speed: 30 feet (or your original race's speed)

Dragon's Resistance: You have resistance to fire damage. Your encounter with dragon magic has left you partially immune to flame.

Draconic Presence: You can channel a fraction of draconic fear. As an action, you can force all creatures of your choice within 30 feet to make a Wisdom saving throw (DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier). On a failed save, a creature is frightened of you until the end of your next turn. Once you use this ability, you can't use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

Survivor's Scars: Your body bears visible scars from dragon fire or claws. These marks don't heal and sometimes glow faintly when you're angry or afraid. You have advantage on Charisma (Intimidation) checks when your scars are visible, but some people react with fear or pity.

Dragon Dreams: You sometimes dream you are a dragon—flying, burning, hoarding. These dreams are vivid and disturbing. You have the Dragon Lore special skill and instinctively understand draconic motivations and behavior.

Roleplay Notes: You survived what kills most people. The experience left you physically and psychologically scarred. You might seek revenge against dragons, understanding of them, or simply try to forget. The dreams won't let you. See Liir's experiences with dragons for examples of how draconic encounters change people.

Living as Touched

The Touched face unique challenges:

Visibility: Many marks can't be hidden. Green skin, glowing eyes, temporal instability—these announce your nature to anyone who sees you.

Suspicion: People fear magic, and you are walking proof of its reality and danger. Unionists may see you as cursed or wicked. Even sympathetic people may keep distance.

Value and Danger: Those who seek magical power may see you as a resource—to study, exploit, or drain. Your blood, your knowledge, your very existence becomes valuable in dark ways.

Identity Questions: Are you still yourself? If magic has rewritten your body and perhaps your soul, what remains of who you were?

GM Notes

Touched characters explore transformation, corruption, heritage, and magical consequences:

  • Use their marks as plot hooks—recognized, hunted, or sought after
  • Explore the tension between power and price
  • Show how visible difference affects social interactions
  • Connect them to magical events and NPCs
  • Let their abilities be both useful and isolating
  • Never make them simply "magic mutants"—they're people dealing with unwanted changes

character/races/dragons.title: Dragons
character/races/dragons.content:
Dragons

"We are older than your cities, older than your gods. We remember when Oz was young and terrible. We remember what you've forgotten."

Overview

Dragons in Oz are not the mighty, ancient wyrms of traditional fantasy. They are smaller, stranger, and infinitely more ambiguous. Are they Animals? Are they reptiles elevated to sentience? Are they magical constructs? Are they fragments of something older than Lurline? No one knows, and the dragons aren't telling—assuming they know themselves.

Physical dragons exist. Liir encountered them during the wars, and they served as military weapons—massive flying reptiles breathing fire and spreading terror. But there's also the Time Dragon, which may not be physical at all but rather a metaphor, a cosmic force, or something that exists simultaneously as dragon and as time itself. The relationship between physical lesser dragons and the possibly-metaphorical Time Dragon is unclear and likely unknowable.

Playing a dragon character means playing something ancient, powerful, unknowable, and deeply *other*. Dragons do not fit into Ozian society. They're too big (often literally), too strange, too bound to forces most Ozians don't understand. This makes them difficult PCs—but for the right campaign and the right player, they offer unique roleplay opportunities.

Are Dragons Playable?

Talk to your DM. Dragons as player characters are experimental and powerful. They're best suited for:

  • High-power campaigns where other PCs are also exceptional
  • Campaigns exploring draconic themes (time, memory, ancient magic)
  • Oneshots or short arcs where balance matters less
  • Groups willing to explore a genuinely alien perspective

If your DM allows dragon PCs, choose between Lesser Dragons (more balanced) or Time Dragon-Touched (more esoteric).

Lesser Dragons (Playable Variant)

These are the physical dragons—the ones Liir encountered, the ones deployed in war. They're massive flying reptiles with intelligence and speech but uncertain souls. Playing a lesser dragon means playing something between beast and person, feared by all and understood by none.

Ability Score Increase: Your Strength score increases by 2, and your Constitution score increases by 2. (This is a +4 total, reflecting draconic power.)

Age: Lesser dragons are poorly understood. They may live 100+ years, but few survive that long given how Ozians hunt them. You're probably young by dragon standards (10-30 years) but already formidable.

Size: Large. You are between 8 and 12 feet long (nose to tail), though much of that is tail. Work with your DM on size challenges—many dungeons and buildings aren't built for Large creatures.

Speed: 30 feet, fly 60 feet

Languages: Common (Ozian), Draconic, and one other language of your choice

Draconic Traits

Natural Armor: Your scales provide excellent protection. When you aren't wearing armor, your AC is 14 + your Dexterity modifier. You can't wear armor designed for humanoids.

Flight: You have a flying speed of 60 feet. This is both incredible advantage and massive target. People shoot at flying dragons.

Fire Breath: You can exhale destructive fire. As an action, you can breathe fire in a 15-foot cone. Each creature in that area must make a Dexterity saving throw (DC = 8 + your Constitution modifier + your proficiency bonus). On a failed save, the creature takes 2d6 fire damage. The damage increases to 3d6 at 5th level, 4d6 at 11th level, and 5d6 at 17th level. After you use your breath weapon, you can't use it again until you complete a short or long rest.

Fearsome Presence: Your draconic nature terrifies most creatures. You have advantage on Charisma (Intimidation) checks. However, you have disadvantage on Charisma (Persuasion) checks with creatures that aren't dragons or dragon-touched—people fear you too much to trust you.

Hunted: Dragons are killed on sight in most of Oz. You are not safe in cities. Gale Force has standing orders to eliminate dragons. Vinkan tribes hunt you for glory. Only in the most remote areas or with powerful protection can you exist openly.

Carnivore: You require meat—a lot of it. You need at least 10 pounds per day. This creates moral and practical problems when other sapient beings exist. Do you eat animals (lowercase)? Do you hunt? Do you eat rations? This must be addressed.

The Question of Dragon Souls

You don't know if you have a soul. You're sentient, clearly. You think, therefore you are. But are you an Animal? A magical creation? A natural creature that happens to be intelligent? The uncertainty affects everything. Unionists say you have no soul. Lurlinites are divided. You suspect even other dragons don't know.

Roleplaying a Lesser Dragon

Personality Traits:

  • I speak bluntly, unconcerned with social niceties I don't understand.
  • I hoard one specific thing obsessively (knowledge, gold, memories, grudges).
  • I'm endlessly curious about small, fragile things that don't exist in dragon life.
  • I measure time in decades, making me patient or frustratingly slow to act.
  • I'm lonely—other dragons are rare, and no one else truly understands me.

Ideals:

  • Freedom: No one will chain or ride me. Ever. (Chaotic)
  • Knowledge: I must understand what I am and where I come from. (Neutral)
  • Survival: Ozians hunt my kind to extinction. I will ensure dragons persist. (Neutral)
  • Power: I am superior to these small, short-lived creatures. (Evil)
  • Understanding: Perhaps I can bridge the gap between dragons and others. (Good)

Bonds:

  • I'm searching for other dragons—I may be the last of my kind.
  • A specific person showed me kindness when all others showed fear; I'm devoted to them.
  • I witnessed the wars where dragons were used as weapons; I seek to prevent it happening again.
  • I'm connected to the Time Dragon in ways I don't understand.

Flaws:

  • My temper is legendary and destructive—I've burned things I didn't mean to.
  • I'm arrogant about my power and dismissive of "lesser" beings.
  • I'm terrified of being captured and used as a weapon again.
  • I struggle with morality around eating meat when prey might be people.

Time Dragon-Touched (Variant)

You're not a physical dragon—or not *entirely*. You're touched by the Time Dragon, which may be a cosmic force, a metaphor given form, or something incomprehensible. You exist partially in time's dream, experiencing reality differently than others. You might appear draconic (scales, wings, eyes) or might look entirely mundane while carrying draconic essence within.

Ability Score Increase: Your Wisdom score increases by 2, and your Intelligence score increases by 1.

Age: Uncertain. You may have lived decades, centuries, or you may be young but remember things from deep time. Age is unreliable when you're touched by temporal forces.

Size: Medium (or Small, DM's discretion)

Speed: 30 feet

Languages: Common (Ozian), Draconic (you speak it in your dreams), and one other

Time Dragon Traits

Temporal Awareness: You exist slightly outside normal time. You have advantage on initiative rolls and can't be surprised while conscious. You sometimes act before you consciously decide to, responding to future events.

Dream the Dragon's Dream: Once per long rest, you can enter a trance for 1 minute and experience time as the Dragon does—all moments simultaneous. During this trance, you can ask one question about past, present, or future, and the DM must answer truthfully (though cryptically). This ability is powerful but often maddening.

Ageless: You don't age normally. You may look the same age for decades, or age rapidly then stop, or exist at multiple ages simultaneously. Time is unreliable around you.

Connection to the Clock: You instinctively know the direction and approximate distance to the Clock of the Time Dragon. You're drawn to it and disturbed by it in equal measure.

Temporal Instability: Reality sometimes treats you as if you're from a different time. You have disadvantage on Charisma checks with people who instinctively sense something is *wrong* about when you exist. However, you have advantage on saving throws against effects that manipulate time.

Roleplaying a Time Dragon-Touched

You see time as a river, a web, a dream. Past, present, and future blur. You mourn deaths before they happen. You celebrate victories you haven't achieved yet. This is both gift and curse—knowledge without the ability to change fate, awareness without presence. You're profoundly isolated, experiencing existence in a way no one else can understand.

Dragons in Society

Dragons don't have society in the traditional sense. Lesser dragons are solitary, territorial, and too rare to form communities. Time Dragon-touched individuals are too scattered and strange to unite. The closest thing to dragon "culture" is:

  • Hoarding: All dragons hoard *something*—gold, knowledge, memories, time itself. This isn't greed (though it can be); it's how dragons order their existence.
  • Long Memory: Dragons remember. They hold grudges across decades. They recall kindnesses for generations. They are the living memory of Oz's deep past.
  • Solitude: Dragons are alone. Even when they're with others, they're alone in ways those others can't understand.

GM Notes

Dragon PCs are challenging to run:

  • Power Level: Lesser dragons are stronger than standard races—compensate with challenging encounters
  • Size Issues: Large PCs create logistical problems; address them creatively
  • Social Isolation: Dragons are hunted; this limits where they can go openly
  • The Soul Question: Never answer definitively whether dragons have souls
  • Time Complexity: Time Dragon-touched abilities can break campaigns if abused—set clear limits
  • Use Sparingly: Dragon PCs work best when rare and special

character/races/winged-monkeys.title: Winged Monkeys
character/races/winged-monkeys.content:
Winged Monkeys

"We did not ask to be made. We did not ask for wings or for the Cap's binding. We are slaves who dream of flying free."

Overview

Winged Monkeys are not natural creatures. They were created—though by whom and for what original purpose is lost to time. What's known is that they are bound by the Golden Cap, a powerful artifact that grants its wearer absolute command over all Winged Monkeys. Whoever holds the Cap can command them three times, and the Monkeys must obey without question, without resistance, no matter how cruel or self-destructive the order.

This makes Winged Monkeys fundamentally unfree. They are sentient, intelligent, and capable of independent thought and action—but only until someone wearing the Golden Cap speaks. Then they are puppets, slaves, tools. The violation of will is absolute and cannot be resisted. No saving throw. No immunity. Just obedience.

Despite this, Winged Monkeys are people. They have personalities, relationships, dreams, and fears. Between commands, they live their lives as best they can. Some serve willingly (or pretend to, for survival). Others dream of freedom. A few seek to destroy the Golden Cap entirely, though this has proven impossible. The Cap is indestructible, and even if it weren't, destroying it might kill all Winged Monkeys simultaneously—their existence is bound to it.

Are Winged Monkeys Playable?

Yes, but with significant caveats. Playing a Winged Monkey means playing a character who can be instantly enslaved by whoever holds the Golden Cap. This creates narrative tension but also serious consent and safety issues. Before allowing a Winged Monkey PC:

  • Discuss in Session Zero how the Golden Cap will be handled
  • Establish whether the Cap appears in the campaign and who controls it
  • Get explicit player consent for potential loss of agency
  • Agree on safety tools (X-Card, Lines & Veils) for slavery/control themes
  • Consider whether the Cap is destroyed, hidden, or inactive in your setting

If these conversations go well, Winged Monkey PCs offer unique roleplay opportunities around freedom, identity, and the weight of potential slavery.

Racial Traits

Trait Description
Ability Score Increase Your Dexterity score increases by 2, and your Wisdom score increases by 1.
Age Winged Monkeys reach adulthood around age 12 and live to about 50-60 years. However, their magical nature may extend lifespans under certain conditions.
Size Small. Winged Monkeys stand between 3 and 4 feet tall, with wingspans of 8-10 feet.
Speed 30 feet, fly 50 feet
Languages Common (Ozian), and Simian (a language shared among Winged Monkeys and some ape Animals)

Flight

You have a flying speed of 50 feet. You can't use this flying speed if you're wearing medium or heavy armor. Unlike birds, your wings are powerful enough to carry significant weight—you can lift and carry allies while flying (within normal carrying capacity limits).

Nimble Acrobat

You have proficiency in the Acrobatics skill. Additionally, you have advantage on Dexterity (Acrobatics) checks made to escape grapples or bonds (except those imposed by the Golden Cap, which cannot be escaped).

Pack Tactics

Winged Monkeys fight as coordinated units. When you hit a creature with a melee attack, one ally within 5 feet of you has advantage on their next attack roll against that creature before the end of their next turn. You instinctively support your troop.

Prehensile Feet

Your feet are as dexterous as hands. You can use them to hold objects, make checks requiring manual dexterity, or wield weapons (though this requires practice). While flying, you can carry items or grapple creatures with your feet, leaving your hands free.

The Golden Cap's Binding

You are magically bound to the Golden Cap. Whoever wears the Cap can command you three times, and you must obey absolutely. This is not mind control—you remain aware and horrified—but your body obeys against your will. After the third command, the Cap passes to another wearer. You have no saving throw against this effect. It is fundamental to your existence.

In Game: If the Golden Cap appears and is used on you, work with your DM to roleplay the horror and violation appropriately. The PC remains aware but controlled. After the command is fulfilled, they regain agency but carry the trauma. This should be handled with extreme care and never used casually.

Alternative: In some campaigns, the Golden Cap is destroyed, lost, or its power is inactive. Discuss with your DM whether your character is still bound or has somehow been freed.

Created Nature

You were created by magic, not born naturally. You don't know who made you or why. You have advantage on Intelligence (Arcana) checks related to magical creation, transformation, or bindings—you understand these forces from the inside. However, you're haunted by the question: were you meant to be slaves, or did someone pervert your creation?

Winged Monkey Society

Winged Monkeys form tight-knit troops of 10-30 individuals. These troops provide identity, support, and protection in a world that sees them as monsters or tools.

Troop Structure: Each troop has a leader (usually the oldest or wisest, not necessarily strongest). Decisions are made collectively, and members defend each other fiercely. When one Winged Monkey is threatened, the entire troop responds.

Territories: Troops claim territories—usually remote areas like the Vinkus mountains or deep Gillikin forests—where they can live relatively free. They build nests in high places, value aerial mobility, and avoid ground-dwelling societies when possible.

The Cap's Shadow: All troop decisions are made with awareness that the Golden Cap could appear at any time. Troops hide, scatter, or prepare defenses against Cap-wielders. Some troops have protocols for what to do if one member is Cap-controlled (flee, restrain, or even mercy-kill the controlled member rather than let them be used). These are grim calculations.

Relationship with Others: Winged Monkeys are feared and often hunted. Elphaba famously used the Golden Cap to command them, and while some Monkeys respected her, others hated her for the violation. Later cap-wearers were often crueler. Winged Monkeys have little reason to trust anyone who might claim the Cap.

Freedom Dreams

Every Winged Monkey dreams of freedom from the Golden Cap. Proposed solutions include:

  • Destroy the Cap: Attempted countless times; always fails. The Cap is indestructible, and some believe destroying it would kill all Winged Monkeys.
  • Hide the Cap: If no one knows where it is, no one can use it. But it always resurfaces.
  • Rewrite the Binding: A powerful enough spellcaster might be able to alter the Cap's magic. But this requires Grimmerie-level power and knowledge.
  • Transcend the Binding: Perhaps if Winged Monkeys change fundamentally—through magic, evolution, or will—they could break free. This is more philosophy than plan.
  • Accept It: Some Winged Monkeys believe freedom is impossible and focus on living well in the moments between commands.

Roleplaying a Winged Monkey

Personality Traits:

  • I value freedom above all else and become anxious when confined or controlled.
  • I'm fiercely loyal to my troop—they're the only family I have.
  • I'm suspicious of anyone who shows too much interest in magical artifacts.
  • I collect small freedoms—choosing my own name, owning something, making decisions—and treasure them.
  • I speak bluntly about slavery and violation; I won't let people forget what the Cap does.
  • I'm endlessly curious about choice and free will, studying how others make decisions.

Ideals:

  • Liberation: I will free myself and all Winged Monkeys from the Cap. (Good)
  • Revenge: I will make everyone who used the Cap suffer as we suffered. (Evil)
  • Community: My troop is everything; I protect them above all. (Lawful)
  • Agency: Every choice I make proves I'm more than a slave. (Chaotic)
  • Acceptance: I cannot change what I am, only how I respond. (Neutral)
  • Destruction: If the Cap can't be destroyed, I'll destroy everything connected to it. (Chaotic)

Bonds:

  • My troop leader saved me from a Cap-command gone wrong; I owe them my life.
  • I'm searching for the Golden Cap to hide or destroy it.
  • Someone once showed me kindness without demanding service; I'm devoted to them.
  • I remember every person who used the Cap on me; I will face them again.
  • I believe I can break the binding through sheer will; proving this is my life's purpose.

Flaws:

  • I panic when I see golden objects, fearing they might be the Cap.
  • I'm so desperate for freedom that I reject any authority, even helpful guidance.
  • I have nightmares about being commanded and wake screaming.
  • I sometimes test people by asking them to give me orders, seeing if I can refuse.
  • I'm convinced everyone wants to enslave me, making trust nearly impossible.

Winged Monkeys and Animals

Are Winged Monkeys Animals? This is debated:

Arguments For: They're sentient, speak, and resemble primate Animals. They deserve the same rights and recognition.

Arguments Against: They're created beings, not natural evolution. Their binding to the Cap makes them fundamentally different.

Winged Monkey Perspective: Many Winged Monkeys see parallels with Animal persecution and sympathize with the Animal Resistance. Some join resistance movements. Others note that Animals face oppression but can theoretically be free—Winged Monkeys can be instantly enslaved by an artifact, which is a different and perhaps worse violation.

GM Notes

Winged Monkey PCs require careful handling:

  • Consent is Mandatory: Never spring Golden Cap control on a PC without prior agreement
  • The Cap as Plot Device: If used, the Cap should create meaningful story, not just rob player agency
  • Trauma and Recovery: Being Cap-commanded is traumatic; address this narratively
  • Freedom Themes: Explore what freedom means when it can be instantly revoked
  • Troop NPCs: Give the PC connections to other Winged Monkeys who matter
  • Breaking the Binding: Consider whether the campaign might achieve this impossible goal

Related Entries

  • Elphaba Thropp - Used the Golden Cap
  • Animals (Sentient) - Overview
  • Mammals (Animal) - Apes and monkeys
  • The Animal Resistance
  • Hybrid & Uncertain Status - Similar creation questions
  • The Grimmerie - Might hold answers to breaking bindings
  • The Vinkus - Common Winged Monkey territory
  • Puppet-State (Condition) - What Cap-control feels like

character/classes/the-unionist.title: The Unionist
character/classes/the-unionist.content:
The Unionist

"In the name of the Unnamed God, I bring order to chaos, law to disorder, unity to division."

Unionists are the ordained clergy and zealous champions of Unionism, the state-sanctioned religion of Oz. They wield divine magic granted by their unwavering faith in the Unnamed God, enforcing spiritual conformity and rooting out "heresy" wherever they find it. Whether serving as parish priests ministering to the faithful, inquisitors hunting down Lurlinite cultists, or military chaplains blessing troops, Unionists represent the spiritual arm of state power.

The Doctrine of Unity

The Unionist Church teaches that all of Oz must be united under one faith, one law, one truth. Diversity of belief is seen as spiritual sickness, Animal consciousness as theological impossibility, and magic outside church control as dangerous heresy. Unionists believe the Unnamed God has chosen them to bring order to a chaotic world—even if that order must be imposed by force.

Class Features

As a Unionist, you gain the following class features.

Hit Points

  • Hit Dice: 1d8 per Unionist level
  • Hit Points at 1st Level: 8 + your Constitution modifier
  • Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per Unionist level after 1st

Proficiencies

  • Armor: Light armor, medium armor, shields
  • Weapons: Simple weapons, maces, warhammers
  • Tools: None
  • Saving Throws: Wisdom, Charisma
  • Skills: Choose two from History, Insight, Intimidation, Medicine, Persuasion, Religion

Equipment

You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

  • (a) a mace and shield or (b) a warhammer (if proficient)
  • (a) scale mail or (b) leather armor or (c) chain mail (if proficient)
  • (a) a light crossbow and 20 bolts or (b) any simple weapon
  • (a) a priest's pack or (b) an explorer's pack
  • A holy symbol (the Unionist Eye), a prayer book, vestments

The Unionist Table
